I was excited to see it focus on debunking persistent myths in development aid, and it got me thinking about the myths I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdve encountered working in advocacy, government relations, and  communications at the Gates Foundation for the past decade. One constant refrain about aid that I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdve heard, particularly in more recent years living in Europe, is this: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdWe have to choose between helping the poor here at home and helping the poor abroad.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 03 Feb 2014 01:23:00 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>5</numberOfComments><author>Joe Cerrell</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/M/MP-MZ/myth2carousele39d1dcfbb15499fab5abb9a86800dc9__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>#SmartAid</topic><program>Poverty</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{D34F6C48-07E7-4C1D-B183-493012360454}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2014/01/Myth-Poor-Countries-Arent-Doing-Their-Part-to-Fund-Their-Own-Development</link><a10:author><a10:name>Gargee Ghosh</a10:name></a10:author><title>Myth: Poor Countries Aren\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt Doing Their Part to Fund Their Own Development </title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2014/01/Myth-Poor-Countries-Arent-Doing-Their-Part-to-Fund-Their-Own-Development"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/P/PP-PZ/pp00000536fc92f52c548e59d1dc15eaabf84d4__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>More often than not, poor countries are in fact funding their own development with their own resources.</p></description><pubDate>Fri, 24 Jan 2014 01:53:56 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>1</numberOfComments><author>Gargee Ghosh</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/P/PP-PZ/pp00000536fc92f52c548e59d1dc15eaabf84d4__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>#SmartAid</topic><program>Poverty</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{A974ECB1-AAB5-415E-8EBB-EF8C0CA9B102}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/07/Transparency-Accountability-and-CitizenLed-Development</link><a10:author><a10:name>Raymond C.  Offenheiser</a10:name></a10:author><title>Transparency, Accountability and Citizen-Led Development</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/07/Transparency-Accountability-and-CitizenLed-Development"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/M/MA-ME/marthahighre19a16f4f5a9e4f119ed12b75c1087d82__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>We realize that to empower citizens and build strong communities, it is necessary to harness the power of community-based ideas and resources and work hand-in-hand with communities to bring these ideas to fruition.</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 15 Jul 2013 10:57:00 -0700</pubDate><numberOfComments>2</numberOfComments><author>Raymond C.
